Intro.p: Describes the role an API Client has at a Provider or other EducationOrganisation.

Description.p: Organisation and OrganisationRelationship master data access
StaffPersonal and StaffAssignment user provisioning access
Credential and LearningStandard master data access
Learning Support Register read-only access
SMS read and write access to a single Provider with a single access token
SMS read and write access to multiple Providers with a single access token
SMS write-only access via the Sync endpoint to a single Provider with a single access token
SMS write-only access via the Sync endpoint to multiple Providers with a single access token

Intro.p: Address type allows an address to be categorised according to its component structure. Address type can be used to build processing rules for validating, managing and presenting addresses.
Address type is independent of the use of the address by any party. To describe how a party may use an address (residence, billing, term address etc) see AddressRoleType

Description.p: Also called 'Street' addresses, The most general, and widely used type of address, and can contain the widest variety of components
In general a thoroughfare address will include components for a number, a roadname, and a locality.
They cannot contain any of the components specific to a delivery service, rural post delivery, or water address.
These addresses are used to find a location.
Example: 30 - 40 Lambton Quay, Wellington, 6165
Defined by New Zealand Post, these addresses are assigned by NZ Post for customers who purchase a rural delivery service (mail and also other goods).
They will have the same number and roadname components as the street address, and may have the same region component.

They do not have a component that identifies the locality the address is within. The locality and city or town components are replaced by components that identify the rural delivery route (RD number), and the town from which the rural delivery route starts and finishes (the mail town). Only addresses of this class can contain these components.
Example: 121 Waitaha Road, RD 1, Ross, 7885
Defined by New Zealand Post, and used exclusively for NZ Post services other than standard mail delivery. Addresses in this class include PO Box, Private Bag, and Counter Delivery addresses.
Example: Private Bag 2345, Auckland, 1142

Where properties have no road access, but do have access to water frontage (coastline or riverbank or lakefront), a water address uses the name of a water feature (for example, islands, rivers, bays, or peninsulas).
Example: 235 Lochmara Bay, Queen Charlotte Sound, Marlborough Sounds
A foreign address identifies a location outside of New Zealand.
Example: Rudolf-Diesel-Strasse 14, 54595 Prüm, Germany

Intro.p: Code set denoting the type of individual or group that determined the appeal outcome.
Code set denoting the type of assessment evaluation taking place, e.g. formative or summative.

Code denoting the nature of the assessment process; Primary assessment against NZ Curriculum or Te Marautanga o Aotearoa; Secondary assessment against NCEA, Cambridge, International Baccalaureate, or similar.

Description.p: Learner is being assessed against assessment against NZ Curriculum or Te Marautanga o Aotearoa; includes teacher's overall judgement, specific competency tests conducted manually or with the help of recognised assessment tools.
Learner is being assessed in an externally provided qualification system such as NCEA, Cambridge Education,
International Baccalaureate, or similar.

Intro.p: Code set denoting the role of the provider in the assessment, e.g. Assessing Provider, Location Provider.
Code set denoting the status of the student's registration for an assessment task, e.g. applied, approved, withdrawn.
Denotes the request type to NZQA for a Digital Exam/ Paper Exam or Digital Submission / Physical Submission.
Code set denoting final result and score values that are pre-defined for certain assessments, e.g. NCEA.

Description.p: Number Knowledge Stage 1 - Emergent
Number Knowledge Stages 2-3 - Counting All
Number Knowledge Stage 4 - Advanced Counting
Number Knowledge Stage 5 - Early Additive
Number Knowledge Stage 6 - Advanced Additive
Number Knowledge Stage 7 - Advanced Multiplicative
Number Knowledge Stage 8 - Advanced Proportional

Intro.p: Codes denoting the current status of the assessment task.
The timeframe of the assessment, e.g. Mid-Year, End of Year.
Standard code set denoting the tests available within an assessment tool that may be used in an assessment task.
Standard codes denoting assessment tools that may be used in an assessment task.
Standard codes denoting the type of assessment the student is sitting for the assessment task.

Value.Text: Tā te Pouako i whakarite ai

Intro.p: Code set denoting the possible attendance code groups, e.g. Present, Justified and Unjustified.
Code denoting presence, absence or the reason for non-attendance at school, or class.

Value.Text: Te haere ki te Mātauranga Kē
Internal school appointment or activity – Dean, DP, sports administrator, coach, attendance officer etc.
Te hui ki te Kura – Tumuaki Tuarua, Kaiako Hākinakina, Āpiha Kura etc.
Absent with an explained but unjustified reason
I ngaro engari he kōrero i puta, kāre he take whakamana
Absent due to short-term illness/medical reasons
He ngaronga nā runga i te māuiui
Justified absence – reason for absence within the school policy
He ngaronga whakamana – ka taka mai i raro i te ritenga ā-kura
No information provided – truant (or throw-away explanation)
Kāre he kōrero – he whakatau (whakamārama rānei)
Examination or unsupervised study. Student is on the school-site
Whakamātautau, te ako noa rānei – ki te kura
Attending an off-site school-organised activity such as a trip/camp
He haerenga nā te kura i whakarite pērā i te haerenga, i te noho puni
Removed (temporarily) from regular class (internal school student isolation)
I tangohia (taupua nei) mai i te akomanga (he mahi ā-kura ki te whakawehe i te ākonga)
Exam leave – unsupervised study – student is off-site
Haerenga whakamātautau – kei waho atu i te kura
Te hararei i te wā o te kura
Te haere ki tētahi Rāngai Mātātahi
Te haere ki te Pokapū Tūmahi
Attending a Health Camp/Regional Health School/Residential School
Te Haere ki te Puni Hauora/Kura Hauora ā-Rohe/Kura Tūtahi
Kua uru ki ngā tono ā-Kōti
Hōtaka Kura Tuarua, Kura Wānanga (me ngā Kura Ahumahi)

Intro.p: Code set denoting the type of attendance being recorded for the student.
Code set denoting type of object or person the student was directing their behaviour at, e.g. Staff Member, Student, Desk, Chair.
Code set denoting the reasons for which a persons biographical data may have changed.

The citizenship or residency status of a person, principally recorded in order to determine eligibility for education services hence limited to indicating New Zealand, Australian or Other residency. Based on SIF Australia AUCodeSetsAustralianCitizenshipStatusType

Description.p: Indicates a residency other than NZ or Australia
Includes Australian residents classified as NZ resident once arrived in NZ

Intro.p: A standardised method of describing how (or when) a communication channel may be used to communicate with a party. Where a party has more than one electronic contact type (eg several phone numbers), this provides context for deciding which to use. A communication usage type may apply to a phone number, email address or generic communication channel.

Description.p: Allows the school to decide which of a caregiver's communication channels is to be used when reporting a medical incident occuring to the learner.
Allows the school to decide which of a caregiver's communication channels is to be used when sending an SMS (TXT) message.
Allows the school to decide which of a caregiver's communication channels is to be used when reporting a learner's unexplained absence.
Allows the caregiver to decide which of a school's communication channels is to be used when notifying of a learner's intended absence.

Intro.p: Code set denoting the role of the person who gave consent on behalf of the student, e.g. Whānau, Student.
A code denoting the status of the Credential throughout its life-cycle.

Description.p: The Credential is being developed, and is not yet available for granting as an Attainment.
The Credential is no longer available granting as an Attainment
The Credential is available for granting as an Attainment
The Credential has been superceded (probably by a subsequent Credential) but this version is still available for granting as an Attainment.

Intro.p: Ethnicity is the ethnic group or groups that people identify with or feel they belong to. Ethnicity is a measure of cultural affiliation, as opposed to race, ancestry, nationality or citizenship. Ethnicity is self perceived and people can belong to more than one ethnic group. The permissible values consists of any value from the Statistics NZ - Ethnicity New Zealand Standard Classification 2005 v2.0.0 Depending on usage, ethnicity may be defined at levels 1 to 4.

Intro.p: Code denoting the type of healthcare service provided by a StudentContact.

An iwi, or Māori tribe, is one of the largest kinship groupings and is generally made up of several hapū that are all descended from a common ancestor. Hapū are clusters of whānau where the whānau is usually an extended family grouping consisting of children, parents, often grandparents, and other closely related kin.
Sourced from Statistics NZ - Iwi and Iwi related groups statistical standard v1.0.0.0

Intro.p: The role of the key contact in the Wellbeing Alert.
The level of instruction that is made in the selected language.

Description.p: Student is taught in the specified language for more than 20 and up to 25 hrs per week (81-100% of total time). Ākonga i ākona ki tētahi reo mō te 20 tae atu ki te 25 hāora i te wiki (81-100% o te wā katoa).

Student is taught in the specified language for more than 12.5 and up to 20 hrs per week (51-80% of total time). Ākonga i ākona ki tētahi reo mō te 12.5 tae atu ki te 20 hāora i te wiki (51-80% o te wā katoa).

Student is taught in the specified language for more than 7.5 and up to 12.5 hrs per week (31-50% of total time). Ākonga i ākona ki tētahi reo mō te 7.5 tae atu ki te 12.5 hāora i te wiki (31-50% o te wā katoa).

Student is taught in the specified language for more than 3 and up to 7.5 hrs per week (12-30% of total time). Ākonga i ākona ki tētahi reo mō te 3 tae atu ki te 7.5 hāora i te wiki (12-30% o te wā katoa)
Student is taught in the specified language for 3 hrs per week. Ākonga i ākona ki tētahi reo mō te 3 hāora i te wiki

Student is taught in the specified language for less than 3 hours per week or as a separate subject (0-11% of total time). Ākonga i ākona ki tētahi reo mō te iti iho 3 hāora i te wiki, hei akoranga kē (0-11% o te wā katoa).

Value.Text: iti iho 3 hāora i te wiki

Description.p: Student is learning Taha Māori. E ako ana te Akonga i te Taha Māori.

Intro.p: A code denoting the nature of the relationship with another LearningStandard

Description.p: The related LearningStandard is a predecessor to this LearningStandard, and is superceded by it.
The related LearningStandard is a successor to this LearningStandard, and it supercedes this LearningStandard.
The related LearningStandard is a prerequisite to this LearningStandard, and students should have completed the learning in that LearningStandard before embarking on the learning in this one.
The precise nature of the relationship between the two LearningStandards not known, but the fact that they are related is known.

Intro.p: Indicates the operational status of an organisation.

Description.p: SIF AU uses the term ‘Pending’

Intro.p: The role played by a person in an organisation where that person is recorded as a contact. The role definition is used to recognise similar functions across organisations, however individuals with the same role may be given different position titles that differ from the generic role description. For example, a principal may have a title of ‘headmaster’.

Code set denoting the status of the relationship between the two organisations. Set to Active when: EffectiveDate => today's date and ExpirationDate is NULL or ExpirationDate > than today's date. Set to Inactive when: EffectiveDate < today's date or ExpirationDate =< today's date.
A code describing the nature of the relationship between a pair of Organisations.

Description.p: Source Provider sends learners to the related Provider for the provision of some classes. Exact student and class details will be recorded in co-enrolment flavour of StudentProviderEnrolment.
Source Provider contributes learners to the related Provider, once the learners have completed education at the source Provider.
Source Provider is a Teen Parent Unit which is operated as part of the related Provider. Learners who are also parents and attend classes at both the Teen Parent Unit and the host school.

Source Provider is an Activity Centre which is operated as part of the related Provider. Learners who have been identified as being at risk of disengaging from mainstream Schooling attend classes at both the Activity Centre and the host school.
Source Organisation represents a Ministry Local Office, and the related organisation represents the Provider (or other organisation) that has an established relationship with the local office.
Source Organisation represents a School, and the related organisation represents an attached unit (Teen Parent Unit, Activity Centre etc)
Source Organisation represents an ECE Service Provider, and the related organisation represents a Licensed ECE Service that is part of (or a member of) the ECE service provider

Value.Text: Licenced ECE Service - ECE Service Provider

Description.p: Source Organisation represents an ECE Service Provider, and the related organisation represents a Playgroup (or other ECE service), that is part of (or a member of) the ECE service provider
Source Organisation represents an RTLB (Resource Teacher; Learning and Behaviour) Cluster, and the related organisation represents a Provider that is a member of the cluster.
Source Organisation represents a Learning Support Cluster, and the related organisation represents a Provider that is a member of the cluster
Source Organisation represents a Kāhui Ako | Community of Learning, and the related organisation represents a Provider that is a funded member of the Kāhui Ako
Source Organisation represents a Kāhui Ako | Community of Learning, and the related organisation represents a Provider that is an unfunded member of the Kāhui Ako

Source Organisation represents a national body of an external organisation, and the related organisation represents the Provider (or other organisation), that is part of (or a member of) the national body

Intro.p: Describes the roles for organisations within the education sector, e.g. School Sector Institution, Learnign Support Cluster, etc.
Describes the organisation type of the provider, indicating the services provided, function or purpose of the organisation.
Code set denoting the type of person that was involved.
The post school activity the student is moving on to once they have exited the school.
Code set denoting why the student's pre-enrolment was cancelled.
Code set denoting how the student's pre-enrolment was cancelled.
The authority by which the provider is authorised to provide education services. Describes the ownership/operation or registration status of an educational institution.

Description.p: Also known as 'State: Non-Integrated'
Owned by another organisation, funded from Vote Education.

Intro.p: Records the status of a potentially multi-year Provider enrolment, which goes through a different life-cycle to the single-year school enrolment.

Description.p: Student has applied to become a Student at the Provider, this pre-enrolment has been received, and is being processed by the provider. It has not yet been accepted or declined by the provider.
The Provider has processed the application, validated it against school zoning rules, and other acceptance criteria.
The provider has accepted the enrolment and will have a place for the Student if they choose to take it up.
Student has accepted the enrolment and is expecting to take up the enrolment at the agreed future date.
The enrolment application has been declined by the Provider, or discontinued by the Student, prior to becoming an ACTIVE enrolment.
The student has taken up the enrolment, and has attended classes for the first time.
The Student has left the Provider, after the enrolment was made ACTIVE

The enrolment has been accepted by the Provider, taken up by the Student, and the student has attended their first day; but the enrolment is unable to be set to ACTIVE, because there is still an ACTIVE enrolment for the student at a (previous) provider.
Once the blocking Provider has put their enrolment to WITHDRAWN, this enrolment can be moved to 'ACTIVE'.

Intro.p: An enumeration of valid SIF DataObject names, to be included in Object References

Description.p: A generic organisation that operates within the education sector; but doesn’t provide education services.
A recognised provider of education services such as ECE Service, School or TEI
A recognised relationship between two providers of education service.
A Provider defined course that Students enrol in, and may be assessed for, and achieve passes in.

A curriculum standard or the like published by a national body, professional association or other interested party. The LearningStandard describes a set of learning that students are expected to undertake.
All the personal, contact and demographic information relating to a staff member, who might be a teacher or other employee of a Provider.
Records assignment of a Staff member to a particular Role at a Provider or other EducationOrganisation.
Contains all the personal information related to the student.
Contains all the personal information about a person who is a part of a Student's whānau.
A relationship between a person who is a part of a Student's whānau and that Student
A student’s association with an education provider for the purpose of receiving educational services.
Identifies a particular class or other group of students.
Records detail about the attendance spans for a single student at a single provider during a single day.
Provides a summary of a student's daily attendance and membership information for a given provider during the time period between the StartDate and EndDate, inclusive.

Provides information about a particular assignment or other assessment task, to be undertaken by one or more Students at some time. Defines the task separately from each student's attempting the task.
The student's registration for an assessment task they are intending to participate in.
Record of a student's attempt at a particular assessment task.
Records the result achieved by a single student at a particular assessment task.
Records a student gaining an Attainment e.g. NCEA Qualification, Learning Standard etc.

A qualification or other award granted by a national body, professional association or other interested party. The Credential describes an award that is made to the learner at the successful completion of a particular learning programme. eg: NCEA Level 1; University Entrance; NCEA Level 2 Chemistry;
Alert indicating to teachers and systems that this student has a 'concern' that needs to be known for 'duty of care', which could be Medical, Legal or other.

Core Wellbeing Characteristic that is integral to the Student. This may be a Medical condition, special needs or a characteristic such as a known disability or any other characteristic or condition that is student specific and impacts their learning.

Record of an event happening that impacts on a school's duty of care to its students. The event records both positive and negative behaviours and is not just the recording of a discipline incident or an accident.
A record of the outcome and follow ups generated by a WellbeingEvent.
Records detail of any appeal or request made by involved parties in regard to a negative/punitive Wellbeing Response that was the result of a student Wellbeing Event.
Information about a student's interests and academic, career and social goals.
Provides information on a co-curricular or extra-curricular activity in which a student participates during a given school year.
Contains information pertaining to a student's learning support.
A curriculum progress and achievement reports provided for a student. Used in technology centres the host provider, to report on student progress to their base school.
Contains information pertaining to a response to a student's learning support need(s).

Intro.p: Code set denoting the role the related organisation is playing in this relationship.

Description.p: Role applies to School/ECE's membershp of RTLB Cluster
Role applies to School/ECE's membershp of RTLB Cluster
Role applies to School/ECE's membership of Learning Support Cluster
Role applies to School/ECE's membership of Learning Support Cluster
Role applies to School/ECE's membership of Learning Support Cluster
Role applies to School/ECE's membershp of Kāhui Ako
Role applies to School/ECE's membershp of Kāhui Ako
Role applies to School/ECE's membershp of Kāhui Ako
Role applies to School/ECE's membershp of Kāhui Ako
Role indicates that an ECE is a member of an ECE Service Provider.
Role applies to School/ECE's membership of a Local Office
Role indicates that a school/ECE is a member of a national body.

Intro.p: A standardised method of describing the personal relationship between two persons. Such a relationship arises from two persons belonging to the same family or closer community or as a consequence of sharing living arrangements.

Description.p: Please Specify

Intro.p: Religious affiliation is the self-identified association of a person with a religion, denomination or sub-denominational religious group.
Sourced from Statistics NZ - Religious Affiliation 1999 v1.0.0.0

Value.Text: Church of Christ and Associated Churches of Christ
Other Church of Christ and Churches of Christ nec

Intro.p: Code set denoting the role of the person who administered the physical restraint to the student.
Code set denoting the type of debriefing that occurred, e.g. staff, or student and parent/caregiver.
Code set denoting a question that was asked about a student physical restraint incident.

Value.Text: First time the student has been physically restrained?
The student was physically restrained more than once during the day?
The student has an Individual Behaviour Plan?
Physical restraint was a part of the plan?
Was the staff member who applied restraint a teacher or authorised staff member?
Role of staff member who applied the restraint?
Did the staff member who applied the restraint receive any training prior to the incident?

Intro.p: A code set denoting the reason physical restraint was used on the student.

Value.Text: Serious and imminent risk to safety

Intro.p: Code set denoting if the school has boarding and if so, if it is for girls only, boys only or both.
Code set denoting the classifications that can be given to a school.

Value.Text: Contributing with Year 7 and 8 Bilingual Students

Intro.p: A summary description of the gender of students that a school accepts, indicating the type of school from a gender perspective.
A type of student enrolment with a school. Allows differentiation of concurrent enrolments, eg base vs other.

Description.p: The school that the student is considered to be primarily enrolled with, especially for the purposes of reporting and Ministry funding. Typically the student will spend most of their school time at this school.
Indicates an enrolment that is concurrent with the student's base enrolment at another school.

Indicates an enrolment with a school (typically Te Kura - The Correspondence School) which provides remote/distance learning; this means that the student remains at their base school (or at home) for all classes covered by this enrolment.

Intro.p: A code list denoting the School Management Systems (SMS) that are in use by Providers.

A description of the gender of students that the school accepts at a certain year level or other instructional grouping. For use at the year level or course only, rather than school level. For instance a school may accept boys only in year 11 but both girls and boys at years 12 and 13.
The type of score metric used for an assessment task result.

Description.p: NZQA Achievement Standards: Not Achieved, Achieved, Achieved with Merit, Achieved with Excellence
Student is assessed to be at one of the levels defined by The National Curriculum: 1A, 1B through 5A, 5B
NZQA Unit Standards: Not Achieved, Achieved
Recorded as either stage numbers 1-8 or 7 codes: E, CA, AC, EA, AA, AM, AP

Intro.p: Code set denoting that the score is an over-arching final aggregate score derived from a collection of other scores, or the fact that the score is derived from a multi-stage marking and moderation process, e.g. inital, interim, moderated and final scores for a single assessment.
Code set denoting the role the source organisation is playing in this relationship.

Description.p: Source organisation is a Ministry local office
that has an established relationship with the local office.
Source organisation is a School that has the related organisation as an attached unit.
Source organisation is a an ECE Service Provider
that has the related organisation ECE Service as a member.
Source organisation is an RTLB (Resource Teacher; Learning and Behaviour) Cluster
that has the related organisation Provider as a member.
Source organisation is a Learning Support Cluster
that has the related organisation Provider as a funded or unfunded member.
Source organisation is a Kāhui Ako | Community of Learning
that has the related organisation Provider as a member.
Source organisation is a National Body that has the related organisation Provider as a member or branch.

Intro.p: A classification of geographical boundaries or statistical areas as defined by Statistics NZ’s geographic hierarchy.

Description.p: Area units are aggregations of meshblocks. They are non–administrative areas that are in between meshblocks and territorial authorities in size. Area units must either define or aggregate to define, regional councils, territorial authorities and urban areas.
Statistics NZ Classification of Area Unit 2013 v1.0.0
The general electoral districts as constituted under the Electoral Act 1993.
Statistics NZ General Electoral District 2014 v1.0.0

(aka Local Board within Auckland) Local boards provide governance at the local level within Auckland Council. They enable democratic decision making by, and on behalf of communities within the local board area.
Statistics NZ Community Board 2013 v1.0.0
Māori electoral districts are the voting districts for parliamentary elections for people who choose to be on the Māori Electoral Roll.
Statistics NZ Māori Electoral District 2014 v1.0.0
A meshblock is the smallest geographic unit for which statistical data is collected and processed by Statistics New Zealand.

A meshblock is defined by a geographic area, which can vary in size from part of a city block to a large area of rural land. Each meshblock borders on another to form a network covering all of New Zealand, including coasts and inlets and extending out to the 200-mile economic zone.
Statistics NZ Statistical Standard for Meshblock 2013 v1.0.0
The top tier of local government in New Zealand, defined by the Local Government Act 2002, which requires the boundaries of regions to conform as far as possible to one or more water catchments.

When determining regional boundaries, the Local Government Commission gave consideration to regional communities of interest when selecting water catchments to be included in a region. It also considered factors such as natural resource management, land use planning and environmental matters.
Statistics NZ Regional Council 2013 v1.0.0

The second tier of local government in New Zealand, defined under the Local Government Act 2002 as a city council or district council. There are 67 territorial authorities consisting of 12 city councils, 53 districts, Auckland Council, and Chatham Islands Council.
Statistics NZ Territorial Authority 2013 v1.0.0

Urban Areas are statistically defined areas with no administrative or legal basis. There is a three part hierarchical sub-division of urban areas into: main urban areas, secondary urban areas, minor urban areas. Together the populations in main, secondary and minor urban areas comprise the statistically defined urban population of New Zealand.
The urban area classification is designed to identify concentrated urban or semi-urban settlements without the distortions of administrative boundaries.
Statistics NZ Urban Area 2013 v2.0.0

Wards are defined under the Local Electoral Act 2001 and result from the division, for electoral purposes, of the district of a territorial authority. The ward system was designed to allow for the recognition of communities within a district and to increase community involvement in the local government system.
Statistics NZ Ward 2013 v1.0.0

Intro.p: Standard codes denoting special assessment conditions that a student requires when sitting an assessment.
Special Education district a provider may belong to

Value.Text: Whakatū, Te Tau Ihu o te Waka-a-Māui, Te Tai Poutini

Intro.p: Code set denoting whether or not this is an Active or Inactive assignment for the staff member. Set to Active when: StartDate => today's date and EndDate is NULL or EndDate > than today's date. Set to Inactive when: StartDate < today's date or EndDate =< today's date
The subset of available roles when assigning a staff member to an Organisation
Code set denoting the type of reflection that the staff member performed.

Value.Text: What did you try before the restraint?

Intro.p: Describes the role a staff member has at a Provider or other EducationOrganisation.

Description.p: Includes job titles such as 'Dean', 'House Leader', etc.
Organisation and OrganisationRelationship master data access
StaffPersonal and StaffAssignment user provisioning access
Credential, Attainment and LearningStandard master data access
Learning Support Register read only access
SMS read and write access to a single Provider with a single access token.
SMS read and write access to multiple Providers with a single access token.
SMS write-only access via Sync endpoint to a sinlge Provider with a single access token.
SMS write-only access via Sync endpoint to multiple Providers with a single access token.

Intro.p: Describes the status of a staff member's employment at a Provider or other Organisation.

Code set denoting the status of the staff member's assignment to a teaching group. Set to Active when: StartDate => today's date and EndDate is NULL or EndDate > than today's date. Set to Inactive when: StartDate < today's date or EndDate =< today's date.
Code set denoting the role the staff member is performing within the teaching group, e.g. Teacher, Teacher Aide, Student Teacher.
Code set denoting achievement objectives against which a student can be assessed within a Learning Strand.
Code set denoting the level of progress the student has made against the learning strand achievement objectiv. e.g. Beginner, Proficient, and Advanced.
Standard codes denoting the group of the activity the student is participating in, e.g. sport, art, cultural, music.
Standard codes denoting the type of activity the student is participating in, e.g. rugby, drama, Kapa Haka, Violin.
Code set denoting what the student is consenting or not consenting to.

Description.p: To use and share photographs of the student
Seek medical treatment in an emergency when the caregiver cannot be contacted
Administer Panadol
This value is for learning support.

Value.Text: Parental Consent To Share With Next ECE Or School
Whakaaetanga Tuari ki te Kura Kōhungahunga, ki te Kura rānei
Authority to release student's NZQA results to a tertiary institution
Share Student NZQA Information with Tertiary Providers

Intro.p: Code set denoting the status of the student contact's relationship. Set to Active when: StartDate =< today's date and EndDate is NULL or EndDate > than today's date. Set to Inactive when: StartDate > today's date or EndDate =< today's date.

Student classification for MoE funding purposes. Codes in this list are hierarchical. Students can only be allocated one TYPE code (even though they may belong to more than one of the groups listed below). To allocate a code to an individual student, start at the top of the list and work down. Use the first code that applies to the student.

Description.p: An International student who meets full tuition costs on their own or from funds provided to them by sponsors other than NZAID.
A student who is enrolled in an Alternative Education programme, for Funding Year Level they should be reported only between Year 9 and Year 13 (inclusive).
A student (and dependants) studying in New Zealand under an exchange programme approved by the New Zealand Government.
Code to be used for students attending on Roll Count Day, but not paying fee and not funded; e.g. students with Eligibility Criteria “28 Day Waiver” and “Extended 28 Day Waiver”.
A student who has returned to school following a break of at least 1 year and is at least 19 years old on 1 January of the Roll count year.
EXAMPLE: Roll count year = 2017 if student is 19 years old on 1 Jan 2017 their student type = AD if there has been a break in their learning cycle.
A student who has continued at school and is at least 19 on 1 January of the Roll count year.
EXAMPLE: Roll count year = 2017 if student is 19 years old on 1 January 2017 their student type = RA as there has not been a break in the students learning cycle.

A New Zealand student or a student treated for funding and staffing purposes as a New Zealand student who is also not yet 19 years at 1 Jan of the roll count year. This includes students in general classrooms and those in special needs units.

A regular student (i.e. a student aged under 19 years at 1 January of the roll count year) who meets the eligibility criteria, but whose enrolment would cause the roll of the TPU to exceed the set maximum.

Value.Text: Teen Parent Regular Student Over Maximum Roll
Ranga Mātātahi, Ākonga kua aua atu i te taumata rārangi

Description.p: An adult student who is enrolled in a Teen Parent Unit (TPU) where the enrolment at the TPU has continued beyond the end of the year in which the student reached 19 years old. The enrolment of this student causes the roll of the TPU to exceed the set maximum.

Value.Text: Teen Parent Adult Student Over Maximum Roll
Ranga Mātātahi, Ākonga Pakeke kua aua atu i te taumata rārangi

Description.p: A student enrolling at the TPU as an adult student (i.e. was at least 19 on 1st January of the year when they first enrolled at the TPU), and who fits within the TPU’s maximum roll.

A student who is enrolled in a Teen Parent Unit (TPU) and is at least 19 years old on 1 January of the current year. These students may continue to be enrolled in the TPU after the end of the year in which they turn 19, their Student Type however will then be changed to TPRAE – Teen Parent Enrolled Continuing Adult Student.

Value.Text: Teen Parent Eligible and Enrolled Regular Student
Ranga Mātātahi me ngā Ākonga kua uru

Description.p: A student who is enrolled in a Teen Parent Unit (TPU) where the enrolment at the TPU has continued beyond the end of the year in which the student reached 19 years old.

Value.Text: Teen Parent Enrolled Continuing Adult Student
Ranga Mātātahi kua uru hei Ākonga Pakeke e haere tonu ana

Description.p: A student who attends this school for some courses but is enrolled at another school where a majority of instruction occurs.
Student who is in a Satellite class of a Special School.

Value.Text: Student in a Satellite Class of a Special School
Ākonga o te akomanga kē o te Kura Motuhake

Description.p: A student who is not attending the school on the day of the roll count and there is no documentation to support their absence from the school.
Student is enrolled in a separately funded unit.

Value.Text: Student in a Separately Funded Unit
Ākonga kei ranga whai pūtea motuhake

Intro.p: Standard codes denoting the type of interest the student likes to do.

Code set denoting the status of the student's teaching group enrolment. Set to Active when: StartDate => today's date and EndDate is NULL or EndDate > than today's date. Set to Inactive when: StartDate < today's date or EndDate =< today's date.
Code set denoting the type of student voice being heard, e.g. their interests, goals, voice (comments, opinions).
Codes denoting Subject Areas defined by the NZ Curriculum and Te Marautanga o Aotearoa.

Description.p: Applicable to both NZ Curriculum and Te Marautanga o Aotearoa
Applicable to both NZ Curriculum and Te Marautanga o Aotearoa

Applicable to both NZ Curriculum and Te Marautanga o Aotearoa

Applicable to both NZ Curriculum and Te Marautanga o Aotearoa

Applicable to Te Marautanga o Aotearoa

Provides the means of identifying the type of group such as Roll class, Subject class or Homeroom and allows systems to treat them accordingly

Description.p: The TeachingGroup is a class only used for taking daily attendance.
The TeachingGroup is a class only used for teaching.
The TeachingGroup is a class used for both teaching and roll taking.

Intro.p: Code set denoting a class or subject area from the technology curriculum that the progress report covers.
Code set denoting the technology curriculum level that the student's progress report is being made against. e.g. 2, 3, 4 or 5.
Code list denoting the learning strands from the Technology curriculum that can be covered as part of a technology class.

Records the source of the identity or eligibility verification, that has been made. Mostly it is merely a record of the kind of document that has been presented; but occasionally it is down to Principal or Ministry discretion / approval.

Description.p: Applies if the child was born before 1 Jan 2006
Applies if the child was born on or after 1 Jan 2006

Description.p: Including COK, TKL or NIU. (Current or Expired)
If the child was born before 1 Jan 2006

ProtectionOrder, CustodialOrder, etc.
Sub-categories
Gifted and Talented, Disability, etc.

Intro.p: Code set denoting the outcome of a wellbeing appeal.
Standard codes denoting the status of the Wellbeing Appeal.
Standard codes denoting the type of award that has been achieved as part of a Wellbeing Response.
Standard codes denoting the second level category of the Wellbeing Characteristic.

Value.Text: Congenital malformations, deformations and chromosomal abnormalities

Intro.p: Standard codes denoting the first level category of the Wellbeing Characteristic. (Note: The second and third levels are Category and SubCategory)
Codes denoting the priority level of the characteristic in relation to other characteristics within the same classification.
Code set denoting the status of the Wellbeing Characteristic.
Standard codes denoting the third level category of the Wellbeing Characteristic.

Code set denoting codes that provide an additional layer of detail around a wellbeing characteristic sub category. For examples for the learner’s support need sub category, e.g. if the support need of ‘Vision’ is selected for the user, the sub needs ‘Low Vision’ and ‘Blind’ are available to further define the type of vision issue the learner has. Not all support needs have sub needs.
Code set denoting the actions that can be taken as a result of the Wellbeing event.

Description.p: Consequence for referral is pending. Referral will be modified when “action taken” is determined.
Consequence for referral results in student attending classes on a Saturday.
Consequence for referral results in student being placed in a different educational setting.
Consequence for referral results in 1-3 day period when student not allowed on the bus.
Consequence for referral results in involvement in community service activities or projects.
Consequence for referral results in student meeting with administrator, teacher, and/or parent (in any combination).

Value.Text: Huihuinga matua, kaiako me te ākonga

Description.p: Consequence for referral results in student being dismissed from school permanently.
Consequence for referral results in a period of time spent away from scheduled activities/classes during the school day.

Value.Text: Rāhuitia ki roto o te kura

Description.p: Consequence for referral results in student receiving individualized instruction specifically related to the student’s problem behaviors.
Consequence for referral results in student being unable to participate in some type of privilege.
Consequence for referral results in administrative decision that is not listed. Staff using this area will specify the administrative action taken.
Consequence for referral results in a 1-3 day period when student is not allowed on campus.

Value.Text: Rāhuitia ki waho o te Kura

Description.p: Consequence for referral results in parent communication by phone, email, or person-to-person about the problem.
Consequence for referral results in apologizing or compensating for loss, damage, or injury; community services.
Consequence for referral results in student spending time in the office away from scheduled activities/classes.
Consequence for referral results in student spending time in a specified area away from scheduled activities/classes.

Intro.p: Standard codes denoting the first level category of the Wellbeing Event. (Note: The second and third levels are Category and SubCategory)
Standard codes denoting the second level category of the Wellbeing Event. (Note: The first and third levels are CategoryClass and SubCategory)

Value.Text: Abuse, threats, harassment or intimidation of staff
Aggressive physical contact against a student
Abuse, threats, harassment or intimidation of a student
Damage to, or theft of property
Other violation of Code of Conduct (classroom managed)
Possession, use or supply of substances or objects with restricted sale
Possession, use or supply of illegal substances or objects

Intro.p: Code set denoting locations where a Wellbeing Event incident may have took place.

Description.p: The area used for art classes and activities.
Areas used by students for taking care of personal needs.
The area inside the bus.
The area used for bus loading and unloading.
The area used for breakfast and lunch.
Areas used for instructional purposes.
Areas shared by students and staff for specific activities.
Area used for group computer classes and activities.
Areas used for physical education activities.
Areas designated for passing from one activity/class to another.

Value.Text: Ngā huarahi haere ki ngā akomanga

Description.p: The area designated for research and study.
The area used by students to prepare for and completing physical education classes and/or sporting events.
The area used by students for music activities (e.g., music class, choir, band).
An area beyond the property boundary of the school and not affiliated with a school activity.

Value.Text: A waho atu i te Kura

Description.p: The area used by school staff for primary school business and management.
The location for problem behavior event occurs in a location that is not listed.
Areas used for parking vehicles during school hours.
The outside area used for recess breaks
Areas used for infrequent activities that occur in and/or out of school.

Value.Text: He kaupapa motuhake, he huihuinga, he haerenga

Description.p: Area used for athletic/special events.
The location of problem behavior event is not known or undetermined.
The area of a school used for vocational classes and activities.

Intro.p: Code set denoting the type of major behaviour problem identified as part of the Wellbeing Event.

Description.p: Student delivers verbal messages that include swearing, name calling, or use of words in an inappropriate way.

Value.Text: Reo whakataki/Reo Pakirara/ Reo kohukohu – Nui rawa

Description.p: Student plans and/or participates in malicious burning of property.
Student delivers a message of possible explosive materials being on-campus, near campus, and/or pending explosion.
Student engages in refusal to follow directions or talks back.

Value.Text: Ātete/Kāre e whakarongo/Kāre e aro mai – Nui rawa

Description.p: Student engages in behavior causing an interruption in a class or activity. Disruption includes sustained loud talk, yelling, or screaming; noise with materials; horseplay or roughhousing; and/or sustained out-of-seat behavior.
Student wears clothing that does not fit within the dress code guidelines practiced by the school/district.
Student is involved in mutual participation in an incident involving physical violence.

Student is involved by being in possession of, having passed on, or being responsible for removing someone else's property; or the student has signed a person’s name without that person’s permission, or claims someone else’s work as their own.

Value.Text: Te Tāwhai/Te whānako/Te Tuhi whānako – Nui rawa

Description.p: Student delivers socially rude or dismissive messages to adults or students.
Student uses gesture, dress, and/or speech to display affiliation with a gang.

Value.Text: Te mau kākahu Kēne – Nui rawa

Description.p: The delivery of disrespectful messages in any format related to gender, ethnicity, sex, race, religion, disability, physical features, or other protected class.
Student engages in inappropriate, consensual (as defined by school) verbal and/or physical gestures/contact, of a sexual nature to another student/adult.

Value.Text: Te whai aroha pakirara – Nui rawa

Description.p: Student is in an area that is outside of school boundaries (as defined by school).

Value.Text: Tētahi wāhi pakirara/Wāhi rāhui – Nui rawa

Description.p: Student delivers message that is untrue and/or deliberately violates rules.
Student engages in problem behavior not listed.
Student engages in actions involving serious physical contact where injury may occur (e.g., hitting, punching, hitting with an object, kicking, hair pulling, scratching, etc.).
Student participates in an activity that results in destruction or disfigurement of property.
Student leaves or misses class without permission.
Student is late (as defined by the school) to class or the start up of the school day (and Tardy is not considered a minor problem behavior in the school).
Student engages in inappropriate (as defined by school) use of cell phone, pager, music/video players, camera, and/or computer.

Value.Text: Te whakamahi hē i te hangarau – Nui rawa

Description.p: Student receives an ‘unexcused absence’ for ½ day or more.
Student is in possession of or is using alcohol.
Student is/was in possession of substances/objects readily capable of causing bodily harm and/or property damage (matches, lighters, firecrackers, gasoline, lighter fluid).
Student is in possession of or is using illegal drugs/substances or imitations.
Student is in possession of or is using tobacco.
Student is in possession of knives (greater than 6 in., less than 6 in.) and guns (real or look alike), or other objects readily capable of causing bodily harm.

Value.Text: Te kai/mau rākau riri – Nui rawa

Description.p: The delivery of direct or technology-based messages that involve intimidation, teasing, taunting, threats, or name calling.

Intro.p: Code set denoting the type of minor behaviour problem identified as part of the Wellbeing Event.

Description.p: Student engages in brief or low-intensity failure to follow directions or talks back.
Student delivers low-intensity, socially rude or dismissive messages to adults or students.
Student engages in low-intensity, but inappropriate disruption.
Student wears clothing that is near, but not within, the dress code guidelines defined by the school/district.
Student engages in low-intensity instance of inappropriate language.
Student engages in any other minor problem behaviors that do not fall within the above categories.
Student engages in non-serious, but inappropriate physical contact.

Value.Text: Te pa ā-ringa/Te tukituki – Iti noa

Description.p: Student engages in low-intensity misuse of property.

Value.Text: Te whakamahi hē i ngā taputapu ā-kura – Iti noa

Description.p: Student arrives at class after the bell (or signal that class has started).
Student engages in non-serious, but inappropriate (as defined by school) use of cell phone, pager, music/video players, camera, and/or computer.

Value.Text: Te whakamahi hē i te hangarau – Iti noa

Intro.p: Code set denoting the possible motivation that triggered the Wellbeing Event.

Value.Text: Kāore i mārama te take o ngā whanonga whakararu a te ākonga

Intro.p: Codes denoting the type of restraint used on a student during a Wellbeing Event.

Description.p: No restraint or seclusion was used.
Any measure or condition used to immobilize or reduce the ability of a student to move his or her torso, arms, legs, or head freely.
The use of both restraint and seclusion.
The involuntary confinement of a student alone in a room or area from which the student is physically prevented from leaving or believes they cannot freely exit.

Intro.p: Code set denoting the severity of the Wellbeing Event.
Standard codes denoting the third level category of the Wellbeing Event. (Note: The first and second levels are CategoryClass and Category)

Value.Text: Understands the purpose and need for rules
Seeks help from a responsible adult
Alerts others to risks and dangers
Helps someone or something in need
Shows consideration of impact of actions on others
Gives back to the greater good
Helps others to reach their goals
Shows mutuality (sharing a feeling, action or relationship)
Shows reciprocity ("I scratch your back, you scratch mine")
Works to be a valued member of a team
Use of a weapon or object - Staff
Struggling to be free of a physical restraint - Staff
Use of a weapon or object - Student
Struggling to be free of violation of personal space or deprivation of liberty - Student
Active refusal to follow reasonable instructions
Dress code breach without reasonable explanation
Breach of Department acceptable use agreement
Persistent personal use of a MED when not permitted
Inappropriate uploading of text, images or audio
Public posting of messages that bring the school or Department into disrepute

Intro.p: Standard codes denoting the time period of the Wellbeing Event.
Standard codes denoting the category a Wellbeing Response belongs to.
Standard codes denoting the status of the Wellbeing Response.
A reusable code set for yes, no, and not required values.
A reusable code set for yes, and no.
